Name: The Variational Principles of Mechanics (Dover Books on Physics)

ReviewList.Text: Lanczos' book is a compelling analysis of the principles of Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics. It reminds me a bit of Feyman's Lectures on Physics because it focuses on the motivating principles behind advanced mechanics. In an elegant and flowing style, Lanczos guides the reader through a walking tour of the principles of mechanics, peppered with historical footnotes. If you understand how to use mechanics, but want to understand how the underlying principles are developed, this is an excellent choice.

Lanczos makes mechanics feels like art in this superb work. Analytical Mechanics is the foundation of physics and Lanczos has complete command of the theme. The purpose of this book is to make one understand mechanics "from inside" and not to stress methods of problem solving. Lanczos says that very clearly in the preface. The beauty of the book is that it's not in the same category as Goldstein, instead feelink more likely to Landau, so the bad criticism of the 2-star guy comes from someone that missed this.

Lanzcos has his name attached to many area of mathematical physics. Besides that, he is an excellent writer. This book on  variationnal principle of mechanics is the most beautifull and profound one I've read on the subject. This book is well suited for undergrad or grad students, but even for reasearcher who uses the tools of analytical mechanics, it's worth reading it.

I think this book is a wonderful reference for engineers taking a  Lagrangian mechanics/dynamics course. This book dives a little deeper into  the mathematics than most engineering oriented texts. It does so in a lucid  fashion no less.

The book is very readable, and goes into depth about the principles that it was written to cover. As a chemist, I bought this book to learn about calculus of variations for a stat-thermo course as well as understand the reasoning behind the Hamiltonian. It does lack problems, save for asking the reader to clear up some trivial details. If you want a book loaded with exercises and cookbook recipes for solving problems, look elsewhere. If you want to feel like you're sitting through the best physics lecture of your life, get this book.

The most lucid and pedagogical presentation concerning the calculus of variations applied in mechanics. The developments are put in a historical context and the intrinsic connections with Riemannian geometry are explained. Simply, a must-have for everyone interested in really understanding the principles of mechanics.

I am not a mathematician or physicist and my background on these subjects is rather basic, but I have an strong interest and since some years ago have been studying them from books like this. Although this book is probably very dated I really did learn a lot from it. It is extremely well written, clearly and pedagogically. Highly recommendable.

This is probably my favorite book of all time. It is a very rich treatise on analytical mechanics. It does a good job of explaining the philosophy and motivations of the physics, and while the mathematics is difficult, the book assumes the reader already knows it instead of wasting their time. The proofs are well-written and clear. The exercises can be a bit removed form the text, but overall this is simply the best way to learn analytical mechanics.

I am in love with this book. It reads like a true novel. The word choice is elegant and the proofs are unique. It really took me aback, being an undergraduate, at how Newtonian mechanics are not optimal in the majority of dynamic systems that occur in the real world. For most situations, you must rely on more sophisticated mathematics. Also, the proof of the Euler Lagrange equation was unique, as I have always seen it proven differently that the way it was done in this book.

Excellent book, very clear, describing complex information in a very appealing manner. To introduce each concept, the author starts with a description using words and gets to very complex formulae in the easiest way possible. It's an art and a science to teach and present information like that.

This is the classic reference for anybody who is interested in understanding variational principles. I personally chose it because I am interested in understanding the relationship between Hamilton's and Fermat's principles. I higly recommend it even for people who are studying variational principles for the first time but want more than a cursory introduction.

It is a great introduction for engineering students. These topics are often teached in a shortened form and they often unclear for many students. So I have to recommend ths book for everyone who waht really  understand the problem and who need something that is close to thinking of engineers.

It really takes you there. Very insightful and complete. Also, for those who like to know how things developed this book is a gem. I still use Symon's book for my general mechanics class, but Lanczos is absolutely necessary reading.

Great book, interesting, reasonably well written and just a good resource.  Dover offers some great reference works at amazing prices.  Though these are not textbooks proper, they work very well to explain principles, or help one better understand concepts.
A classic for both clarity and style.
Very easy to understand in its presentation
I'm about to take a course in analytical mechanics next year. The teacher is rumored to be horrible. It's a good thing I have this book!
